journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part A: Journal of Power and Energy

title-group.article-title: Rotordynamic performance prediction for surface-roughened seal using transient computational fluid dynamics and elliptical orbit model

contrib-group.aff: Institute of Turbomachinery, Xi’an Jiaotong University, People's Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: Jun Li, Institute of Turbomachinery, Xi’an Jiaotong University, Xi’an 710049, People's Republic of China. Email: junli@mail.xjtu.edu.cn

abstract.p: This article presents a transient computational fluid dynamics method based on the elliptical orbit model to solve the rotordynamic coefficients of the non-axisymmetric rotating turbomachinery. To validate the numerical approach, an arbitrary stator roughened seal, named hole-pattern seal, is taken as an object to investigate the rotordynamic performance at different excitation frequencies. For each case, the transient fluid force is computed by integrating the unsteady pressure on the off-centered rotor surface. The rotordynamic coefficients are obtained by solving the frequency dependent reaction force/seal motion equations. The transient pressure distributions on the rotor and stator are plotted to analyze the influence of the rotor precession on the pressure fluctuation during a period. It shows that the computed leakage rate and rotordynamic coefficients for the hole-pattern seal agree well with the experimental data. Compared to the previous circular orbit model, the present numerical approach for the elliptical orbit model has equivalently high accuracy, but the consumed transient solution time is reduced by 50%.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The reliability of the high-speed turbomachinery depends heavily on good rotordynamic performance of the rotating seals.1–3 In order to enhance the rotor stability, the conventional smooth seal is usually designed to be roughened in the stator surface to reduce the circumferential swirl of the leakage flow.3 Compared to the conventional labyrinth seal, this type of deliberately roughened stator seal (named damper seal) has a larger damping and thus can effectively eliminate the synchronous and sub-synchronous vibration problems for the rotor-bearing system.3,4 Thus recently, the rotordynamic performance of the deliberately roughened stator seal has raised significant research interests.3–7

From the aspect of computational setup, prediction of the rotordynamic performance for the deliberately roughened stator seal is more complex and time-consuming than for the smooth labyrinth seal. For the smooth labyrinth seal, the seal geometry is moving and the leakage flow field is unsteady in the stationary frame of reference. In the rotating frame with referenced orbital velocity, this transient problem can be converted to a steady one thus significantly simplify the numerical approaches. However, for the roughened stator seal with an eccentric orbit, this transient problem cannot be converted into a steady computation in the rotating frame. In this case, the transient solution combined with mesh deformation method is essential to solve the rotordynamic coefficients of the surface-roughened seal. Therefore, it requires longer computational time. Moreover, the grid generation is also time-consuming due to the complexity of the deliberately roughened surface.

In the past three decades, numerical methods have been well developed for the seal-rotor dynamics analysis. For the annular gas seal, the rotordynamic coefficients were initially solved using the simplified one-control-volume bulk flow model.8 Subsequently, Ha and Childs,9 Kleynhans and Childs,10 and Soulas and San Andres11 presented the two-control-volume bulk flow method which is available to predict the rotordynamic performance of the honeycomb (or hole-pattern seal) seal. However, for the two-control-volume bulk flow method, several drawbacks as follows still need to be tackled.
The friction factors for each new design need to be empirically defined before computations.
It lacks of detailed flow information since it is a two-dimensional analysis tool.
The accuracy needs to be further enhanced.

As another numerical method, three-dimensional computational fluid dynamics (CFD) techniques based on solving the Reynolds averaged Navier–Stokes (RANS) equations have been rapidly developed to predict the rotordynamic performance of the rotating seals in the past decade.6,7,12–14 Compared to the bulk flow analysis method, the CFD method has the advantage of providing detailed fluid field, which is useful to reveal the mechanism of the fluid-induced excitation in the seal-rotor system. The steady computational method to solve the rotordynamic coefficients of the smooth labyrinth seal was discussed in detail by Moore,12 in which an approach to transform the unsteady off-centered orbit into a steady one was proposed. Subsequently, Moore and Ransom13 applied this method to analyze the rotordynamic performance of the centrifugal compressors. The transient CFD method for solving the rotordynamic coefficients of the off-centered whirling turbomachinery was systematically described by Guo et al.14 They utilized a three-dimensional CFD method to compute the transient pressure distributions in the squeeze film damper by employing the moving grid method. Then, Chochua and Soulas6 developed a transient CFD method to solve the rotordynamic coefficients of the deliberately roughened stator gas annular seal by utilizing the unidirectional shaking model and mesh deformation method. In their studies, the validity of the transient CFD procedures was demonstrated using the obtained experimental data.4 Subsequently, Yan et al.7 advanced Chochua and Soulas’s6 transient CFD method by adding one more degree of freedom for the rotor precession. In their studies, Chochua and Soulas’s6 unidirectional shaking model was modified into a circular orbit model. Yan et al.’s7 numerical results show that the transient CFD method based on the circular orbit model has a superior accuracy to the two-control-volume bulk flow analysis10 and unidirectional shaking model.6 However, this method (circular orbit model) requires twice of transient computations (forward and backward orbit computations) for a certain excitation frequency thus double the computational time.

The above literatures provide evidence that the transient CFD method has an excellent accuracy in predicting the rotordynamic performance and can reveal more detailed transient flow field for the deliberately roughened stator seal compared to the bulk flow analysis method. However, the long computational time inhibits the transient CFD method from being widely applied in the seal design and evaluation process. In this article, in order to reduce the computational time without moderating the accuracy of the transient CFD solution, a new transient CFD approach based on the elliptical model to solve the rotordynamic performance of the deliberated roughened stator seal is proposed and validated against experimental data. Subsequently, in order to reveal the fluid-induced excitation mechanism, the transient flow fields are also analyzed. It is noted that the present numerical method is also feasible to compute the rotordynamic performance of other non-axisymmetric rotating components, such as bearing, centrifugal impeller, rotor blade, etc.

sec.title: Orbit model description
sec.p: For the annular gas seal rotating with a small motion about the centered position, the reaction forces can be expressed as (1)-[FxFy]=[K(Ω)k(Ω)-k(Ω)K(Ω)][XY]+[C(Ω)c(Ω)-c(Ω)C(Ω)][X·Y·] where Fx, Fy are the reaction forces on the rotor surfaces in x- and y-directions, respectively. (X,Y) and (X·,Y·) are the whirling displacement and velocity of the seal rotor.

To simulate the motion of the deliberately roughened stator seals, Yan et al.7 presented a circular orbit model (which contains two directional motions on the transversal plane of the rotor), as shown in Figure 1. The motion of the rotor follows (2){x=rcos(Ωt)y=rsin(Ωt) Figure 1.
Circular orbit model.7.

To solve the rotordynamic coefficients with the circular orbit model, Yan et al.7 introduced the forward and backward orbit computations to obtain the rotordynamic coefficients in equation (1). Since it requires two transient solutions for each excitation frequency, the computation time will be doubled (for each transient computation, about 15 days is required on one Intel Core2 Quad6600 2.4 GHz CPU computer). In other words, for each excitation frequency, 2 × 15 = 30 days (‘2’ means forward and backward orbit computations) are needed for the circular orbit model to obtain the rotordynamic coefficients. Therefore, the computational time becomes the main drawback and needs to be reduced.

In order to reduce the transient computation time while maintaining the numerical accuracy, this article presents a new numerical approach based on the elliptical orbit model, as shown in Figure 2. For this model, the motion of the rotor can be expressed as (3){x=acos(Ωt)y=bsin(Ωt) Figure 2.
Elliptical orbit model (present).

By substituting equation (3) into equation (1), the relations between the reaction forces and rotordynamic coefficients can be expressed as (4){-Fx=[K(Ω)a+c(Ω)bΩ]cos(Ωt)+[k(Ω)b-C(Ω)aΩ]sin(Ωt)-Fy=[C(Ω)bΩ-k(Ω)a]cos(Ωt)+[K(Ω)b+c(Ω)aΩ]sin(Ωt)

Selecting Ωt=0∘ and Ωt=90∘ case, the rotordynamic coefficients can be calculated as follows (5){k(Ω)=aFy0+bFx'a2-b2K(Ω)=bFy'-aFx0a2-b2c(Ω)=-aFy'-bFx0(a2-b2)ΩC(Ω)=bFy0+aFx'(a2-b2)Ω where the superscripts 0 and ′ denote the Ωt=0∘ and Ωt=90∘ conditions, respectively. For the elliptical orbit model, the rotordynamic coefficients can be computed only once for each excitation frequency. It will cost only 50% computational time compared to the circular orbit model.7

sec.title: Numerical methods
sec.p:
In this study, since the hole-pattern seal has a roughened stator, the transient solution combined with mesh deformation method is utilized. To obtain the transient flow field in the hole-pattern seal, a commercial solver ANSYS CFX11.0 is adopted to solve the transient RANS equations. On the hardware side, a computer with Intel Xeon Core16 E5620 2.40 GHz CPU and 80 GB RAM is used. The fluid is air (ideal gas model). For the temporal discretization, a second-order backward Euler scheme is adopted. The spatial discretization scheme is selected to be high resolution. In order to consider the turbulence and boundary layer effects, the standard k–ε turbulence model with scalable wall function is adopted.15 At the seal inlet, the total pressure (7.0 MPa) and total temperature (17.4°C) are specified according to the experiment.4 The inlet turbulence intensity is specified to be 5%. At the seal outlet, the static pressure is set to be 3.15 MPa. The vibration amplitudes in x- and y-directions are specified to be 2.0 × 10−5 and 3.0 × 10−5 m, respectively. The detailed seal geometry and boundary conditions are listed in Table 1. Table 1.
Seal geometries and operating conditions for the hole-pattern seal.5.
Inlet pressure (MPa) 7.00 Sealing clearance (mm) 0.2
Outlet pressure (MPa) 3.15 Seal radius (mm) 57.37
Inlet temperature (°C) 17.4 Seal length (mm) 85.7
Rotational speed (r/min) 20,200 Hole diameter (mm) 3.175
Inlet pre-swirl 0 Hole depth (mm) 3.302
Hole area ratio 69% Hole number 2668

Figure 3 shows the computational model and structured meshes generated by ANSYS ICEM CFD11.0. Since the hole-pattern seal rotates with an off-centered orbit, a full circumferential geometry is required to be meshed for the computational domain (Figure 3(a)). In order to compare the present numerical results to the circular orbit model7 under a same criterion, the same mesh from Yan et al.7 is used in this study. The total nodes number for the hole-pattern seal is 5.98 million, and the element number is 5.23 million. Figure 3.
Computational model and mesh: (a) computational model and (b) enlarged view of the mesh.

In this study, five different excitation frequencies ranged from 20 to 250 Hz are selected. Table 2 lists the computational time step for each case. Since the orbit periodicity decreases with the increase of excitation frequency, smaller time step is required for the higher excitation frequency case. Table 2.
Computational time step for each excitation frequency.
Excitation frequency (Hz) Whirling speed (rad/s) Periodicity (s) Computational time step (s)
20 125.7 0.05 0.0005
50 314.2 0.02 0.0002
100 628.3 0.01 0.0001
200 1256.6 0.005 0.00005
250 1570.8 0.004 0.00004

At first, the steady flow field is computed to obtain a converged solution which is used as an initialization for the transient computations. In the transient computations, if the root mean square residuals for the momentum and turbulence equations reach 10−5, and the fluctuation of the forces on the rotor surface between the adjacent periods is smaller than 0.1 N, the transient solutions are considered to be converged.

In each time step, the mesh motion of the rotor surface is governed by equation (3). The motion of all remaining nodes is determined by the displacement diffusion model.15 Near the wall boundaries, the mesh stiffness is increased in order to maintain the mesh quality during the transient solutions. On the rotor surface, the transient fluid forces Fx and Fy are computed by integrating the unsteady pressure at each time step. After the converged solution of Fx and Fy has been obtained, the rotordynamic coefficients of the hole-pattern seal can be calculated according to equation (5).

sec.title: Numerical results
sec.p:
Figure 4 plots the rotor displacements in x- and y-directions in the computations. For each excitation frequency during one period, 100 time steps are specified for the transient solution. Figures 5 to 9 illustrate the convergence histories of the reaction forces on the rotor surface at different excitation frequencies (ranged from 20 to 250 Hz). It is seen that the convergent solution is obtained after the first iteration period. Although the motion of the rotor in y-direction is 1.5 times of the x-direction (b = 1.5a), Fy does not equal to 1.5Fx. Taking f = 100 Hz as an example (in Figure 7), the amplitude of Fy is about 26 times of Fx. For each case, the transient fluid force acting on the rotor surface has the same periodicity as the rotor oscillation. However, the phase angle for the transient Fx and Fy are not the same with the rotor orbit. For each case, the phase angle for Fx and Fy are listed in Table 3. Figure 4.
Oscillations of the rotor in x- and y-directions. Figure 5.
Convergence history for force impedances at f = 20 Hz. Figure 6.
Convergence history for force impedances at f = 50 Hz. Figure 7.
Convergence history for force impedances at f = 100 Hz. Figure 8.
Convergence history for force impedances at f = 200 Hz. Figure 9.
Convergence history for force impedances at f = 250 Hz. Table 3.
Phase angle for each excitation frequency.
Excitation frequency (Hz) Phase angle for x Phase angle for y Phase angle for Fx Phase angle for Fy
20 1.5π 0 1.02π 1.44π
50 1.5π 0 1.08π 0.88π
100 1.5π 0 0.68π 0.74π
200 1.5π 0 0.30π 0.82π
250 1.5π 0 0.34π 0.86π

By substituting the transient forces (Figures 5 to 9) into equation (5), the rotordynamic coefficients can be obtained. The comparisons of the computed rotordynamic coefficients between the elliptical and circular orbit models are listed in Table 4. It is seen that the numerical results with these two different orbit models are very close. However, as mention in ‘Orbit model description’, the computational time for the elliptical orbit model is about 1/2 of the circular orbit model. Table 4.
Computed rotordynamic coefficients (E, elliptical orbit model; C, circular orbit model).
k (MN/m) K (MN/m) c (N·s/m) C (MN·s/m) Keff (MN/m) Ceff (N·s/m)
E C E C E C E C E C E C
20 Hz 16.8 16.7 2.7 3.2 −20,476.1 −22,640.8 38,081.0 37,450.3 0.157 0.354 −95,609.2 −95,405.7
50 Hz 15.1 15.0 6.2 6.6 −19,103.4 −19,511.1 33,833.7 33,404.9 0.198 0.470 −14,231.1 −14,335.4
100 Hz 10.6 10.6 14.2 14.3 −14,606.7 −14,495.1 24,838.0 24,770.0 5.022 5.193 7899.6 7899.1
200 Hz 4.0 3.9 25.7 25.5 −6900.0 −6695.2 12,006.0 11,911.1 17.029 17.087 8822.9 8807.5
250 Hz 2.3 2.3 28.7 28.4 −4794.3 −4651.6 8530.5 8547.1 21.169 21.093 7066.3 7082.9

In order to validate the present transient numerical approach, the comparisons between the elliptical orbit model (present), circular orbit model (Yan et al.7), unidirectional shaking model (Chochua and Soulas6), isothermal two-control-volume bulk flow model (ISOTSEAL, Kleynhans and Childs10), and experimental data4 are performed, as shown in Figures 10 to 15. These figures provide the relations between the rotordynamic coefficient and excitation frequency. It can be seen that the numerical results with the present elliptical orbit model are almost coincide with that of the circular orbit model.7 This indicates that the vibration amplitude has little influence on the computed rotordynamic coefficients if the rotor orbits about the seal center with a small motion. In the authors’ previous study,7 the vibration amplitudes are selected to be 2.0 × 10−5 m in both the x- and y-directions. However, in the present numerical approaches, the vibration amplitudes are selected to be 2.0 × 10−5 and 3.0 × 10−5 m in x- and y-directions, respectively. Although the vibration amplitudes are different between Yan et al.7 and this article, the computed rotordynamic coefficients are almost equal. This indicates that both the circular7 and elliptical orbit models (this article) have the same accuracy. And moreover, both the circular and elliptical orbit models have a superior accuracy than that of unidirectional shaking model6 and ISOTSEAL10 with respect to the experimental test.4 It can be concluded that, for the unidirectional shaking model, only one-directional rotor motion will lead to loss of fluid–solid interaction information in the numerical computations. For the ISOTSEAL solutions, since the leakage flow in the seal is usually highly turbulent and non-uniformed, neglecting of the turbulence effect and simplifying of the hole-pattern geometry will introduce additional errors for the rotordynamic coefficients calculations. For the elliptical orbit model, it almost has the same accuracy as the circular orbit model. Also, it only requires half of the computational time in contrast to the circular orbit model. Therefore, it has a superior advantage in the rotordynamic investigations for the non-axisymmetric rotating turbomachinery. Figure 10.
Cross-coupled damping c versus excitation frequency.
CFD: computational fluid dynamics. Figure 11.
Direct damping C versus excitation frequency.
CFD: computational fluid dynamics. Figure 12.
Cross-coupled stiffness k versus excitation frequency.
CFD: computational fluid dynamics. Figure 13.
Direct stiffness K versus excitation frequency.
CFD: computational fluid dynamics. Figure 14.
Effective stiffness Keff versus excitation frequency.
CFD: computational fluid dynamics. Figure 15.
Effective damping Ceff versus excitation frequency.
CFD: computational fluid dynamics.

Table 5 provides the calculated leakage rate using the different methods for the hole-pattern seal. It indicates the leakage rate with the present elliptical orbit model agrees better with the experimental data than that of isothermal two-control-volume bulk flow model10 and unidirectional shaking model.6 For the leakage rate computation, the elliptical orbit model almost has the same accuracy as the circular orbit model, while the leakage rate from isothermal two-control-volume bulk flow model10 is nearly the same as the unidirectional shaking model.6 Table 5.
The computed leakage rate using different methods.
Experiment4 Bulk flow model (ISOTSEAL4) Unidirectional shaking model6 Circular orbit model7 Elliptical orbit model (present)
0.409 kg/s 0.437 kg/s 0.438 kg/s 0.429 kg/s 0.429 kg/s

The pressure fluctuations during a period are contoured on the rotor surface in Figure 16. The impact of off-centered whirling on the pressure distributions on the rotor is obtained for the excitation frequency of f = 20 Hz. It can be seen that the pressure distributions along the circumferential direction is non-uniform during a period. This flow characteristic will lead to the unbalanced fluid forces on the rotor-seal system. For each time step in Figure 16, the pressure contours are in the same pattern. Take A0 ∼ A3 for an example, the higher pressure region which is due to the smaller gap rotates with the same periodicity of the rotor precession. This can also be deduced from Figures 4 and 5. The periodicity of the reaction forces on the rotor (Figure 5) is the same as the rotor orbital periodicity (Figure 4). This can also be explained by considering the sealing clearance variety during a period. In each time step, the clearance along the circumferential direction is in the same pattern. For instance, the position of the minimum sealing clearance rotates with the rotor orbit. Figure 16.
Transient pressure contours on the rotor surface (f = 20 Hz).

Effect of the off-centered orbit on the pressure distributions on the hole-pattern stator is also provided in Figure 17. Because the clearance varying during a period, the compressibility of the leakage flow in the gap and hole region leads to the pressure fluctuation on the stator surface during a period. Take A0 ∼ A3 (Figure 17) for example, the similar as A0 ∼ A3 in Figure 16, the pressure contours shows different distributions in different time step. In other area, non-uniform contours of pressure along the circumferential direction can also be observed. Figure 17.
Transient pressure contours on the stator surface (f = 20 Hz).

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In this article, a transient CFD method based on the elliptical orbit model was proposed to investigate the flow and rotordynamic characteristics for the non-axisymmetric rotating turbomachinery. As a special case, a hole-pattern seal with a deliberately roughened stator was chosen to validate the presented numerical approach.

Based on the experimental tests4 and numerical studies,7 unsteady RANS equations are solved through the commercial software AYSYS CFX11.0 to obtain the transient reaction forces and rotordynamic coefficients for the hole-pattern seal. For each excitation frequency, the computational time for the present elliptical model is about 15 days while several minutes for the bulk flow model. However, the numerical results show that the computed rotordynamic coefficients and leakage rate with the presented elliptical orbit model agree better with the experimental data4 than that of ISOTSEAL10 and unidirectional shaking model.6 Also, the CFD predictions can provide more detailed transient flow field in the deliberately roughened seal than that of the bulk flow method. Additionally, the accuracy of the computed leakage rate and rotordynamic coefficients with the presented elliptical orbit model is almost the same as the circular orbit model.7 However, the transient computation time for the elliptical orbit model is reduced to 50% of the circular orbit model.7

The computed fluid force on the seal rotor, as well as the pressure distributions on the rotor and stator surfaces, has the same periodicity with the rotor orbit. However, the phase angle is shifted which is clearly observed in the present transient solutions. For the annular gas seal with a high rotational speed, the turbulence and compressibility of the leakage flow have a pronounced effect on the fluid forces on the seal rotor. Therefore, for a more accurate computation, these effects should be considered.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work was supported by National Natural Science Foundation (grant number 51106122) and Fundamental Research Funds for the Central Universities of China.
